A Channel that Heats Up

Tobias Koch Â Â Â Â Â  Amos Lapidoth ETH Zurich, Switzerland
Email: {tkoch, lapidoth}@isi.ee.ethz.ch â€ƒâ€ƒ Paul P.Â Sotiriadis Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, USA
Email: pps@jhu.edu
Abstract

Motivated by on-chip communication, a channel model is proposed where the variance of the additive noise depends on the weighted sum of the past channel input powers. For this channel, an expression for the capacity per unit cost is derived, and it is shown that the expression holds also in the presence of feedback.

I Introduction

Continuous advancement in VLSI technologies has resulted in extremely small transistor sizes and highly complex microprocessors. However, on-chip interconnects responsible for on-chip communication have been improved only moderately. This leads to the â€œparadoxâ€ that local information processing is done very efficiently, but communicating information between on-chip units is a major challenge.

This work focuses on an emergent issue expected to challenge circuit development in future technologies. Information communication and processing is associated with energy dissipation into heat which raises the temperature of the transmitter/receiver or processing devices; moreover, the intrinsic device noise level depends strongly and increasingly on the temperature. Therefore, the total physical structure can be modeled as a communication channel whose noise level is data dependent. We describe this mathematically in the following subsection.

I-C The Main Result

Our main result is stated in the following theorem.

Theorem 1

Consider the above channel model. Then, irrespective of whether feedback is available or not, the corresponding capacity per unit cost is given by

CË™â€‹(0)=CË™FBâ€‹(0)=12â€‹(1+Î±)Ë™ğ¶0subscriptË™ğ¶FB0121ğ›¼\dot{C}(0)=\dot{C}_{\textnormal{FB}}(0)=\frac{1}{2}\left(1+\alpha\right) (9)

where Î±ğ›¼\alpha is defined in (2).

TheoremÂ 1 is proved in SectionÂ II. In SectionÂ III we briefly discuss the above channel at high SNR. Specifically, we present a sufficient and a necessary condition on the coefficients {Î±Î½}subscriptğ›¼ğœˆ\{\alpha_{\nu}\} for capacity to be bounded in the SNR.

II Proof of Theorem 1

In SectionÂ II-A we derive an upper bound on the feedback capacity CFBâ€‹(SNR)subscriptğ¶FBSNRC_{\textnormal{FB}}(\textnormal{SNR}), and in SectionÂ II-B we derive a lower bound on the capacity Câ€‹(SNR)ğ¶SNRC(\textnormal{SNR}) in the absence of feedback. These bounds are then used in SectionÂ II-C to derive an upper bound on CË™FBâ€‹(0)subscriptË™ğ¶FB0\dot{C}_{\textnormal{FB}}(0) and a lower bound on CË™â€‹(0)Ë™ğ¶0\dot{C}(0), and it is shown that both bounds are equal to 1/2â‹…(1+Î±)â‹…121ğ›¼1/2\cdot(1+\alpha). Together with (8) this proves TheoremÂ 1.

III High SNR Results

The channel described in SectionÂ I-A was studied at high SNR in [4] where it was asked whether capacity is bounded or unbounded in the SNR. It was shown that the answer to this question depends highly on the decay rate of the coefficients {Î±Î½}subscriptğ›¼ğœˆ\{\alpha_{\nu}\}. We summarize the main result of [4] in the next theorem. For a statement of this theorem in its full generality and for a proof thereof we refer to [4].

Theorem 2

Consider the channel model described in SectionÂ I-A. Then,

where we define, for any a>0ğ‘0a>0, a/0â‰œâˆâ‰œğ‘0a/0\triangleq\infty and 0/0â‰œ0â‰œ0000/0\triangleq 0.
